text: Which of the following is NOT a type of unswitched network?
explanation: Virtual circuit is a type of packet switching used in switched networks, not unswitched networks. Unswitched networks include point-to-point, multi-point, and broadcast configurations.

text: How many links are required to directly connect 10 nodes in an unswitched network?
explanation: To directly connect n nodes, you need n(n-1)/2 links. For 10 nodes: 10Ã—9/2 = 45 links, which demonstrates why unswitched networks with many nodes are unfeasible.

text: What is the main difference between switched and unswitched networks?
options: In switched networks, data passes through intermediate nodes
explanation: In switched networks, data passes through one or more intermediate nodes between the sender and receiver, unlike unswitched networks where nodes are directly connected.

text: Why are switched networks preferred over unswitched networks for large-scale deployments?
options: They are not cost effective to have all nodes directly connected
explanation: It is not cost effective to have all nodes directly connected to all other nodes, especially when nodes are spread out and vast in number, making switching necessary.

text: What is the primary purpose of switching in networks?
options: To get signals to the correct destination
explanation: The primary purpose of switching is to get signals to the correct destination when source and destination are not directly connected.

text: What is the difference between routing and switching?
options: Routing identifies the route, switching transfers data between networks/links
Switching is more secure than routing
explanation: Routing identifies the route traversed by data to get from source to destination, while switching transfers data from one network/link to another.

text: Which of the following is NOT a type of switching mentioned in the lecture?
explanation: Frequency switching is not mentioned as a type of switching. The main types covered are circuit switching, message switching, and packet switching (with its variants).

text: In circuit switching, what happens once a dedicated communications path is established?
options: The path can be optimized during transmission
Circuit capacity must be paid for whether used or not
The path automatically terminates after 5 minutes
Multiple users can share the same path
explanation: Once a circuit is established, circuit capacity must be paid for whether or not it is used, which is one of the characteristics of circuit switching.

text: What is a disadvantage of circuit switching once the route is set up?
explanation: Once the route is set up in circuit switching, it cannot be optimized, which is considered a disadvantage, although it does provide low transmission delays.

text: Circuit switching is most suitable for which type of communication?
explanation: Circuit switching suits human-to-human telephone communications but is less suitable for computer communications due to setup time and inability to handle data bursts.

text: Why is circuit switching less suitable for computer communications?
options: Setup time and cannot handle data bursts
explanation: Circuit switching is less suitable for computer communications because of setup time and its inability to handle data bursts effectively.

text: In space-division switching, what happens to each call?
options: Each call shares the same path
Each call takes a different path through the switch
Each call is divided into time slots
explanation: In space-division switching, each call takes a different path through the switch, with crosspoints that can be turned on or off to establish these different paths.

text: What is a crossbar in the context of space-division switching?
options: A simple space-division switch with crosspoints that can be turned on or off
explanation: A crossbar is a simple space-division switch where crosspoints can be turned on or off to establish different paths for different calls.

text: In time-division switching, how is each call handled?
options: Each call takes a different physical path
Each call is divided into small pieces assigned time-slots
Each call waits in a queue
Each call is broadcast to all destinations
explanation: In time-division switching, each call is divided into small pieces and each piece is assigned a time-slot, with the contents of each time-slot switched independently.

text: What is the function of a multiplexer in time-division switching?
options: To aggregate sessions from N input lines to output running N times faster
explanation: A multiplexer aggregates sessions from N input lines, with the output running N times as fast as the input lines.

text: What does a demultiplexer do in time-division switching?
options: Distributes sessions from one input to N outputs running N times slower
explanation: A demultiplexer distributes sessions from one input line to N outputs that run N times slower than the input.

text: What is Time Slot Interchange (TSI)?
options: A method to encrypt time slots
Writing to shared memory and reading in different order
explanation: Time Slot Interchange (TSI) involves writing data to shared memory and reading it in a different order to achieve the switching function.

text: What is a major efficiency problem with circuit switching?
options: The circuit may be idle much of the time
explanation: A major efficiency problem with circuit switching is that the circuit may be idle much of the time, especially in computer communications, yet resources are still reserved.

text: What type of delay is associated with circuit switching?
options: Time needed to set up the circuit
explanation: Circuit switching has a delay due to the time needed to set up the circuit initially, though it has low delay once the circuit is established.

text: How are messages transmitted in message switching?
options: All at once through a dedicated circuit
explanation: In message switching, entire messages are sent using store-and-forward technique, hop-by-hop through the network.

text: What is a characteristic of message progress in message switching?
options: Messages make intermittent progress as each hop becomes available
Messages are duplicated at each hop
explanation: In message switching, messages make intermittent progress as each hop becomes available, and end-to-end delivery time cannot be guaranteed.

text: What problem can very long messages cause in message switching?
options: They hog buffer space at intermediate nodes and links
explanation: Very long messages can hog buffer space at intermediate nodes and hog the links between them, causing resource utilization issues.

text: What does a packet switching network comprise?
options: A set of nodes (switches/routers) connected by links
explanation: A packet switching network comprises a set of nodes (switches or routers) that serve as intermediate stations, connected by point-to-point or broadcast links.

text: How is the data stream handled in packet switching?
options: Divided into packets, each with data and header
explanation: In packet switching, the data stream is divided into packets, with each packet comprising data and a header containing control information.

text: What does each packet contain in packet switching?
explanation: Each packet in packet switching contains both data (the actual information being transmitted) and a header (control information for routing and handling).

text: How do packets reach their destination in packet switching?
options: By making their way through the network from node to node
explanation: Packets make their way through the network from node to node, with each intermediate station switching incoming packets through links to other nodes until reaching the destination.

text: Which of the following is NOT a type of packet switching mentioned?
explanation: Circuit switching is a different switching method altogether, not a type of packet switching. The types of packet switching are virtual circuit, datagram, and label switching.

text: What happens before data transfer in virtual circuit packet switching?
explanation: In virtual circuit packet switching, a connection is set up between end stations before data is transferred, similar to circuit switching but at the packet level.

text: How are packets sent in virtual circuit switching?
options: Each packet finds its own route
Packets are sent along a pre-chosen route
Packets are broadcast to all nodes
Packets are stored at the source
explanation: In virtual circuit switching, packets are sent along a pre-chosen route that was established during the connection setup phase.

text: What is a disadvantage of virtual circuit packet switching?
explanation: Virtual circuit packet switching has a set-up delay before sending data because a connection must be established between end stations first.

text: What is a Virtual Circuit Identifier (VCI)?
options: A permanent address for each node
An identifier assigned to each packet for its virtual circuit
explanation: A Virtual Circuit Identifier (VCI) is assigned to each packet to identify which virtual circuit it belongs to, and different VCIs are used on each link.

text: In virtual circuit switching, are the same VCIs used on all links?
options: Yes, VCIs remain constant throughout the path
No, different VCIs are used on each link
explanation: Different VCIs are used on each link in virtual circuit switching, meaning the VCI can change as the packet traverses different links in the network.

text: How are packets routed in datagram packet switching?
explanation: In datagram packet switching, packets are routed independently, with each packet making its own routing decisions based on current network conditions.

text: What is an advantage of datagram packet switching regarding setup?
options: No initial circuit setup costs or delays
explanation: Datagram packet switching has no initial circuit setup costs or delays, unlike virtual circuit switching which requires connection establishment.

text: What is a disadvantage of datagram packet switching?
options: Switching each packet is relatively expensive
explanation: In datagram packet switching, switching each packet is relatively expensive because routing decisions must be made independently for each packet.

text: How does datagram switching handle network failures?
options: It adapts to node and link failures during transmission
explanation: Datagram switching adapts to node and link failures during transmission because each packet is routed independently and can take alternate paths.

text: What can happen to packet order in datagram switching?
options: Datagrams may arrive out of order
explanation: In datagram switching, datagrams may arrive out of order because each packet is routed independently and may take different paths with different delays.

text: What does a switch use for routing decisions in a datagram network?
options: Routing table based on destination address
explanation: A switch in a datagram network uses a routing table that is based on the destination address to make forwarding decisions.

text: What happens to the destination address during a packet's journey in datagram networks?
options: It remains the same during the entire journey
It is removed after the first hop
explanation: The destination address in the header of a packet in a datagram network remains the same during the entire journey of the packet.

text: What is the basic principle of label switching?
options: Route at edges, switch in core
Switch at edges, route in core
explanation: Label switching follows the principle of 'Route at edges, switch in core', where routing decisions are made at network edges and simple switching occurs in the core.

text: When is a label attached to a packet in label switching?
options: When it arrives at a label switched network
explanation: A label is attached to each packet when it arrives at a label switched network, typically at the network edge.

text: How do core switches handle packets in label switching?
options: They examine the full destination address
They switch based on the label and substitute a new label for the next hop
They store and forward entire messages
explanation: Each core switch switches the packet based on the label and then substitutes a new label for the next hop, making the switching process very efficient.

text: What happens to labels as packets traverse through a label switched network?
options: Labels are substituted at each hop
Labels are removed after first hop
explanation: Labels are substituted at each hop in a label switched network, with each switch replacing the incoming label with an appropriate outgoing label.

text: What is cell switching?
options: A switching method mentioned in the summary
explanation: Cell switching is mentioned in the summary as another type of switching, though not elaborated upon in the lecture content provided.

text: According to the switching strategies diagram, which switching method shows messages progressing in complete blocks?
explanation: Based on the switching strategies comparison, message switching shows complete messages progressing as blocks through the network, unlike packet switching which shows smaller packet segments.

text: Which switching method would be most appropriate for real-time voice communication?
explanation: Circuit switching is most appropriate for real-time voice communication because it provides a dedicated path with consistent delay characteristics, which is essential for voice quality.

text: Which switching method provides the best resource utilization for bursty data traffic?
explanation: Packet switching provides the best resource utilization for bursty data traffic because resources are shared dynamically rather than being reserved as in circuit switching.

text: What is the main trade-off between virtual circuit and datagram packet switching?
options: Setup overhead vs. per-packet processing overhead
explanation: The main trade-off is between setup overhead (virtual circuits require connection establishment) and per-packet processing overhead (datagrams require routing decisions for each packet).

text: In which scenario would message switching be preferred over packet switching?
options: When network reliability is poor and store-and-forward is beneficial
explanation: Message switching would be preferred when network reliability is poor and the store-and-forward capability is beneficial, allowing messages to wait at intermediate nodes until the next hop is available.

text: What is the primary advantage of using intermediate nodes in switched networks?
options: Reduced total number of required links compared to full mesh
explanation: The primary advantage is the reduced total number of required links compared to a full mesh topology, making large networks economically feasible.

text: Which type of switching allows for the most efficient use of network bandwidth?
explanation: Packet switching allows for the most efficient use of network bandwidth because multiple communications can share the same links simultaneously, unlike circuit switching where bandwidth is reserved.

text: What happens to crosspoints in a crossbar switch?
options: They can be turned on or off
explanation: In a crossbar switch, crosspoints can be turned on or off to establish or break connections, allowing different input-output combinations for space-division switching.

text: What is the relationship between input and output speeds in time-division multiplexing?
options: Output runs at the same speed as input
Output runs N times as fast as input for N input lines
explanation: In time-division multiplexing, the output runs N times as fast as the input when there are N input lines, allowing all inputs to be accommodated in the single output stream.

text: Why is circuit switching inefficient for computer communications?
options: Computer traffic is typically bursty with idle periods
explanation: Circuit switching is inefficient for computer communications because computer traffic is typically bursty with long idle periods, yet the circuit remains allocated and paid for during these idle times.

text: What is a key characteristic that distinguishes packet switching from message switching?
options: Data is divided into smaller units (packets) rather than sent as complete messages
explanation: The key distinguishing characteristic is that in packet switching, data is divided into smaller units called packets, while in message switching, entire complete messages are transmitted.

text: In label switching, what is the main benefit of having labels?
options: Simplified and faster switching in core nodes
explanation: The main benefit of labels is simplified and faster switching in core nodes, as switches only need to look at the short label rather than processing complex destination addresses.

text: Which switching method requires the caller, callee, and all intervening nodes to be available simultaneously?
explanation: Circuit switching requires the caller, callee, and all intervening links and nodes to be available at the same time to establish the dedicated communications path.

text: What is the main disadvantage of having very long messages in message switching?
options: They hog buffer space and links at intermediate nodes
explanation: Very long messages can hog buffer space at intermediate nodes and hog the links between them, potentially causing delays and resource starvation for other messages.

text: Which statement best describes the packet forwarding process in datagram networks?
options: All packets follow the same predetermined path
Each packet is independently routed based on its destination address
Packets are broadcast to all possible destinations
Routing decisions are made only at the source
explanation: In datagram networks, each packet is independently routed based on its destination address, with routing decisions made at each intermediate node.

text: What is the primary purpose of the header in packet switching?
options: To provide control information for routing and handling
explanation: The header in packet switching provides control information necessary for routing and handling the packet, including destination addresses and other control fields needed for proper delivery.
